These solutions should be prepared only on the day of the assay by mixing the previously described reagents. You should mix the solutions in a container of appropriate size wrapped in aluminum foil. Keep the solutions on ice.

Working solution without TPTZ (perform this step only if the sample has color):
Mix the following reagents in a proportion of 10:1:1
Acetate buffer
;
Ultrapure water
;
Iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3.6H2O)
;

Working solution with TPTZ:
Mix the following reagents in a proportion of 10:1:1
Acetate buffer
;
TPTZ solution
;
Iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3.6H2O)
;
To optimize the reaction, an incubation step is needed.

Prepare
microtubes, to be used to store the samples, with the correct information. The number of microtubes depends on the number of samples. You should provide at least five replicates (n = 5) of each sample with at least one control tube per sample. You should also prepare negative and positive control samples. Perform the test at least two times to ensure the results are as correct as possible.

To generate the standard curve, fill the wells of your microplate as described below. You should provide duplicates or triplicates of each point of the curve to make your quantification more precise. Using a micropipette fill the wells in this order: Iron(II) sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4.7H2O) + Ultrapure water + Working solution with TPTZ. Air bubbles should be perforated with a needle to avoid bias in the analysis;

For each sample, fill the plastic microtubes as described below. Using a micropipette fill the tubes in this order: Sample + Ultrapure water + Working reagent without TPTZ or Working reagent with TPTZ. Mix the solution with the pipette tip to homogenize the content;

Incubate all your microtubes at
for
using a dry bath;

Take your samples off the dry bath and let them rest at room temperature for
;
Prepare to read the absorbance of your samples in a microplate reader;
Use a conventional 96-well microplate to run your samples. Before start pipetting, each well of the microplate should be marked for sample identification.

Transfer
of the content of each microtube to its corresponding well in the microplate;

Read the absorbance of the samples at
in a microplate reader;
Prepare to analyze the results obtained after reading the absorbance of the samples;

Subtract the absorbance of the blank wells from the absorbance of the different FeSO4.7H2O concentrations:
Absorbance of FeSO4.7H2O = Absorbance of FeSO4.7H2O - Blank absorbance

Plot in an excel sheet the results from your standard curve. Ferrous sulfate (FeSO4.7H2O) concentrations in µM are plotted on the X axis, while the respective absorbances (Sample absorbance - Blank absorbance) Should be plotted on the Y axis (as shown in the figure below). Insert a scatter plot, add a trend line, line equation, and R² value. The value of R² must be between 0.9 and 1.

Subtract the absorbance of the sample blank wells from the absorbance of the different samples:
Sample absorbance = Sample absorbance - Sample blank absorbance

From the line equation, replace the Y with the sample absorbance (Sample absorbance - Sample blank) and calculate the X value, resulting in Fe2+ concentration in micromoles per liter (µM) in the analyzed sample.

Calculate the amount of Fe2+ in micromoles (µmol) in the final volume of the microtube:
Microtube volume:
Fe2+ concentration found in the lat step ---------- 1000 mL
Y -------------------- 0.31 mL
Y = ...... equivalent µmoles of Fe2+

Calculate the amount of Fe2+ per mL of sample used in the technique:
Y found in the last step ------------ 0.01 mL
Z ------------------ 1 mL
Z = ...... equivalent µmoles of Fe2+ / mL of sample
Results should be expressed as equivalent µmoles of Fe2+/mL of the sample.

description: Considering the role of oxidative stress in the pathology of several diseases and the use of antioxidants as treatment and/or adjuvants in these conditions. Here we propose a protocol to evaluate the antioxidant capacity of compounds by the FRAP method, which is based on the reduction of Fe3+ (ferric) to Fe2+ (ferrous) by antioxidant molecules forming the blue-colored Fe2++ TPTZ complex. This protocol was standardized at LAPCOM (Psychopharmacology and Behavior Laboratory at UFRGS) to assess biochemical parameters in vitro.
